By clicking Continue to join or sign in, you agree to LinkedIn‚ÄôsUser Agreement,Privacy Policy, andCookie Policy. For the first time in 40 years, India's no.1 car is no more a Maruti Suzuki, it's Tata Punch!

In 2024,Tata Motorstook the crown, selling over 2.02 lakh units of the Tata Punch, surpassing the Wagon R‚Äôs 1.91 lakh units.

This marks a significant shift in India‚Äôs car market, where compact SUVs and premium cars are gaining popularity, breaking the decades-long dominance of affordable hatchbacks.

For Maruti Suzuki, which built its legacy on affordable cars, this is a whole new challenge

The Indian car market is evolving, and Tata Motors‚Äô rise could signal a new era for premium and SUV vehicles!Maruti Suzuki India Limited#tatapunch Senior Strategy & Technology Leader | | NEXT 100 CIO Award Winner | Digital Transformation, Cloud & Data | Global Remote | Open to Funded PhD Never purchased a Maruti, I have been using Hyundai, Mahindra Renault during the past decade, due to Safety feature Got my first Tata car couple of years ago, 
I can say that the company has improved its products line compared to the nano/Indica days. Unfortunately the engine refinement and the gearbox, is still behind any Japanese brands. Tata's aftersales service and availability of spare parts always remain in question, whether in metropolitan areas or small towns, . 
In my opinion, Tata may be attracting first-time buyers with its focus on safety features. However, high sales volumes is resulting in delays in servicing appointment, and any major issues can lead to even longer wait times, where things are sorted only through escalations. Considering the current competitive market and the experience I had, it is unlikely that I would choose another Tata car again. Business Analyst | Project Management | JIRA | Agile | Scrum | UAT | API Testing | Blogger | Learning AI I own one and it's remarkable in performance and build quality. Only concern is about mileage which seems a bit on lower side compared to Maruti. Otherwise, I'm consistently engaging some addons to make it feel more & more sturdy and luxurious. I Fix Predictable Revenue Breakdowns in ‚Çπ10‚Äì300 Cr Manufacturing Businesses |
45-Day Revenue Engine | 90-Day Bottleneck Removal | No Ads. No Guesswork. I doubt this trend will last; Maruti's affordability will always reign supreme in India's car market. Never under-estimate Market leaders. Maruti Processes are more superior to Tata , is my assessment . Maruti is more profitable and more successful in Market , enjoys Customer's delight for decades now . I feel Maruti Team is more systematic than tata . Above all , the quality systems of Maruti due to Japanese DNA shall naturally be superior too. The Era has not ended , new era has started , If Tata is doing well in one segment , I am happy for them . Even Mahindra has done a wonderful work . All big 3 , Tata, Maruti and Mahindra must focus on TESLA instead. I would recommend that you also focus on TESLA , even BYD looks Promising now . With EVs in place, the market is going to get heated up soon. Tata has done some good work in Hydrogen and Maruti has its own strategy on Hybrids. Finally , the one with best service and customer centric processes at optimum costing will Lead the market #RDS Trade Monitoring Engineer at Quadeye | Team Lead | HFT | Comfortable working with Open/Closed Source Technologies Sales is one thing but aftersales services is a very important factor. I think Tata should actually work on increasing the number of service centers because the ones that are currently present are too much occupied in solving issues for people and hence they lack in providing good service to the regular customers, even those who are not having problems in their cars.

I have never heard of any other company's cars that have stopped after delivery when people were taking them home. So if that's the kind of quality that Tata is providing in their vehicles, they should work on that as well. Transforming Businesses into Profitable, Sustainable Enterprises | Governance, Industry 4.0 & Cross-Border Leadership TATA is Best in terms of Safety in Affordable Car segment, Maruti is surely least bothered about safety..As people become more and more aware of, they will choose wisely. Indian general public is wise enough to take right decisions, only challenge remains Affordability and service network which TATA is able to meet. Good news though ü´∂ Actually the 40 year domination part is not completely correct.
In the year 2004, Hyundai Santro was the Highest Selling Car in Bharat.
Ironic and sad, that Santro has been pushed into the oblivion and that Hyundai hasn't been able to sustain that glory of its first 8-10 years. Its dominance in small cars has given way to fierce competition in SUVs and EVs: a battleground where Tata Motors , Hyundai Motor Company and Mahindra are rewriting the rules. With the launch of the Victoris and e-Vitara, Maruti is betting on scale, trust and reach to power a comeback. But in a market driven by Gen-Z ambition and technology, can the old king still reign? üîó Read the full cover story to know more. #LinkInComments Also, check out the latest issue, now available on Amazon: https://lnkd.in/g3ahupN4 #MarutiSuzuki #OutlookBusiness #IndianAuto #EVTransition #SUVMarket #TataMotors #Hyundai #Mahindra #AutoIndustry #MakeInIndia #BusinessLeadership || Maruti Suzuki India Limited continues to define India‚Äôs automobile market, accounting for four out of every ten cars sold. Its enduring strength lies in scale, reach and a sharp understanding of shifting market dynamics. From expanding capacity to deepening its dealer network, Maruti has consistently stayed ahead of industry cycles. As the market transitions towards SUVs and electric vehicles, the company faces a new test of adaptability. Can India‚Äôs largest automaker sustain its dominance in an era reshaped by technology and changing consumer preferences? üîóRead the full story. #LinkInComments Also, check out the latest issue, now available on Amazon: https://lnkd.in/g3ahupN4 #MarutiSuzuki #IndianAuto #EVTransition #AutoIndustry #BusinessStory #OutlookBusiness #MakeInIndia #MobilityFuture || Can Maruti Reinvent Itself in the Age of Electric and SUVs? Once the undisputed king of India‚Äôs roads, Maruti Suzuki India Limited is fighting to reclaim lost ground from Tata Motors , Mahindra and KIA Motors . Its market share has slipped from 51% to around 41% as consumer preferences shift from small cars to SUVs and EVs. The automaker is preparing a calculated comeback by setting up EV workshops across 1,000 cities, installing fast chargers every 5 to 10 km in top markets, and projecting EVs to form 15% of its sales by FY31. Critics call it late, while insiders call it strategic. The company‚Äôs strength lies in its scale, affordability and a service network unmatched in India. Having bounced back once before after the 2011 Manesar crisis, can Maruti do it again in the electric era? üîó Read the full story. #LinkInComments Also, check out the latest issue, now available on Amazon: https://lnkd.in/gByrWb9C #MarutiSuzuki #ElectricVehicles #AutoIndustry #EVTransition #BusinessStrategy #MakeInIndia #Mobility #Automotive #OutlookBusiness || Maruti Suzuki is shifting gears ‚Äî this time, towards the global highway. After losing ground to Tata Motors , Mahindra Automotive , and Kia India in India‚Äôs SUV race, the country‚Äôs largest carmaker is finding momentum abroad. Exports are growing nearly 27% a year, helping Maruti Suzuki India Limited overtake Hyundai Motor Company as India‚Äôs top car exporter with over 40% of the PV export market. With a ‚Çπ70,000 crore investment to double capacity to 4 million units and policy tailwinds like lower GST on small cars and PLI incentives for EVs, Maruti‚Äôs comeback plan is taking shape. The e-Vitara, its first electric SUV, is expected to drive this revival ‚Äî but will exports alone help the king reclaim its crown? üîó Read the full story in our latest issue. #LinkInComments Also, check out the latest issue, now available on Amazon: https://lnkd.in/g3ahupN4 #MarutiSuzuki #IndianAuto #Exports #EVTransition #MakeInIndia #OutlookBusiness #AutomobileIndustry #SUVMarket #PLIScheme || Most Selling Cars in India ‚Äì September 2025! India‚Äôs passenger vehicle market in September 2025 reflected robust demand across SUVs, sedans, and hatchbacks, with Tata and Maruti Suzuki leading the charts. 1) Tata Nexon topped the list with 22,573 units, continuing its stronghold in the SUV category. 2) Maruti Suzuki Dzire followed with 20,038 units, reaffirming sedan popularity. 3) Hyundai Creta secured third place with 18,861 units, staying ahead in the premium SUV space. 4) Mahindra Scorpio registered 18,372 units, showcasing solid traction in the SUV segment. 5) Tata Punch clocked 15,891 units, maintaining strong demand in the compact SUV market. 6) Maruti Suzuki Swift and Wagon R posted 15,547 and 15,388 units, respectively. 7) Maruti Suzuki Fronx recorded 13,767 units, while Baleno followed with 13,173 units. 8) Maruti Suzuki Ertiga rounded off the list at 12,115 units, keeping MPVs relevant. With six Maruti Suzuki models in the Top 10, the brand continues its dominance, while Tata Motors and Mahindra strengthen their SUV portfolios. Maruti Suzuki India Limited Hyundai Motor Company Tata Motors Tata Motors Cars Rajesh KR Tarun Garg Bhartendu Singh Virat Khullar Puneet Anand Piyush Darwade Krushant Shah Ravindra Jain Sonali Singh Shailesh Chandra Balaje Rajan Rajesh Abhishek Kumar Ram Suresh Akella Sanjeev Handa Nikhil Dhar Leena Siag Shilpy Roy Shashank Srivastava Tarun Aggarwal #CarBike360 #CarSales #TopSellingCars #September2025 #TataNexon #MarutiSuzuki #HyundaiCreta #MahindraScorpio #TataPunch #MarutiSwift #WagonR #MarutiFronx #Baleno #Ertiga #IndianAutoMarket #CarTrends || As competition intensifies in India‚Äôs passenger vehicle market, Maruti Suzuki India Limited is betting big on SUVs, EVs, and scale to reclaim its long-held dominance. With a ‚Çπ70,000 crore investment, new models like the Victoris, and plans to double capacity to 4 million units by FY31, India‚Äôs market leader is preparing for its most ambitious decade yet. But with Tata Motors , Hyundai Motor Company , and Mahindra accelerating their EV and SUV portfolios, the road ahead will test whether Maruti can truly reinvent its image beyond small cars. üìñ Read the full analysis in our latest issue. #LinkInComments Also, check out the latest issue, now available on Amazon: https://lnkd.in/g3ahupN4 #OutlookBusiness #MarutiSuzuki #AutoIndustry #IndianAutomobile #EVIndia #SUVMarket #TataMotors #Hyundai #Mahindra #MakeInIndia #BusinessInsight || Maruti Suzuki exports hit record high in September, Nissan posts strong growth on GST boost https://lnkd.in/dnwM9tEG Maruti Suzuki India Limited Saurabh Vatsa Nissan Motor India Private Limited #CarSales #AutoIndustry #VehicleExports #IndianAutomotive #NavratriSales #GSTBenefit #RecordExports #AutomobileGrowth #IndianMarket #CarLaunch #NewMagnite #FestiveDemand #GlobalAutomotiveHub #AutomotiveNews #ElectricAndHybridCars #IndianCarMarket #AutomotiveInnovation #CarEnthusiasts || DAY 21/100 INDIAN AUTOMAKERS PLAYING BIG BET. What‚Äôs happening Indian automakers like Tata Motors, Bajaj, Maruti Suzuki, TVS, and Hero want to enter the European EV market. They are doing this in two ways: Buying European companies to get access to advanced design, tech, and branding. Exporting their own EVs (cars, bikes, scooters) directly to Europe. Examples Tata Motors bought Iveco‚Äôs commercial vehicle business in Italy. Bajaj Auto took full control of KTM. TVS bought an Italian design company, Engines Engineering, to make premium vehicles. Hero MotoCorp and Ultraviolette plan to sell their electric two-wheelers in Europe. Challenges Europe‚Äôs car market is sluggish right now (people are buying fewer cars). Chinese EV companies (like BYD) are very aggressive in Europe, making competition tough. Some past attempts by Indian firms in Europe (like TVS‚ÄìNorton, Ashok Leyland in UK) didn‚Äôt succeed. Why it matters Indian companies get access to advanced European tech and design skills. It helps build a premium global brand image. It diversifies revenue ‚Äî not only from India but also from global markets. #EQUITY #AUTOSECTOR #FINANCE || Day 4 of My 100-Day Automobile Journey Maruti Suzuki & the EV Dilemma When I first thought of cars, the first name that came to mind was Maruti Suzuki. In my village, the Maruti 800 was a dream car. Even today, families proudly talk about buying a Swift, Dzire, or WagonR. But here‚Äôs the twist ‚Äî as I‚Äôm researching the automobile sector for my 100-day challenge, I realized: üëâ In the EV race, Maruti is not the leader. It‚Äôs the laggard. üîç What I Found Out Suzuki Motor (parent) has promised a $8 billion EV investment in India. The first EV, eVITARA, has just been shipped ‚Äî 2,900 units exported to 12 European nations. Meanwhile, Tata Motors sold 8,540 EVs in August 2025 alone ‚Äî almost 3x Maruti‚Äôs entire first export batch. Maruti is still relying on hybrids, CNG & petrol dominance ‚Äî which gave them ‚Çπ1,45,115 crore net sales in FY25. Only now, in 2025, they‚Äôre talking about gigafactories & large-scale EV production. ‚ö° Why They Fell Behind (My Reflection) Reading all this, I asked myself: Why did the king of Indian roads fall behind in EVs? And the answers were eye-opening üëá They played safe: focused on ICE cars, afraid EVs wouldn‚Äôt be affordable for the masses. They started late: Tata took the first-mover advantage back in 2020. They had no early battery strategy: no gigafactories, no raw material tie-ups. Their parent company, Suzuki, was itself late to the global EV game. Basically, while Maruti was defending the present, Tata was building the future. üß† My Takeaway This hit me personally because I see how companies (and people like us) sometimes play it ‚Äúsafe‚Äù ‚Äî and by the time we act, someone else has already taken the lead. Maruti still has trust, reach, and scale. But trust alone won‚Äôt win the EV race. The next 2 years will decide if their $8B bet can close the gap, or if Tata has already locked in the crown. üëâ Now I want to hear from you: If you had to place your bet on the future of EVs in India ‚Äî would you back Maruti‚Äôs scale or Tata‚Äôs head-start? Parth Verma The Valuation School #MarutiSuzuki #EVIndia #AutomobileSector #Day4Challenge #LinkedInGrowth || Maruti's Bold Move in SUV Market. Maruti is targeting younger buyers with its new SUV, the Fronx (Victoris), and has different sales channels to avoid competition between its own models. Hyundai‚Äôs Creta Electric sales have dropped this year, but Creta is still very popular, with many loyal customers buying it again or upgrading from smaller Hyundai cars. Maruti offers CNG options in both its new Victoris and Grand Vitara SUVs, providing more choices as demand for CNG vehicles grows. Hyundai still leads in engine power with its turbo motors, a feature that Maruti lacks. While Maruti is making bold moves with more options and a strong sales network, it will be challenging to overtake Hyundai Creta‚Äôs top position in the market. #SUVMarket #AutomotiveIndustry #MarutiSuzuki #Hyundai #IndiaAutomobile S&J Advisory

By clicking Continue to join or sign in, you agree to LinkedIn‚ÄôsUser Agreement,Privacy Policy, andCookie Policy. TATA Punch

We bought the TATA Punch from, Indore.

But we‚Äôre very disappointed with the service. It took more than two weeks to install the charging setup at our home.

On the night of March 31st, we were driving when, all of a sudden, the Punch Electric stopped working. We tried calling TATA support to tow our car, but they didn‚Äôt help us.

After a lot of struggle, we somehow managed to tow the car ourselves and reached home late at night.

This is just one scenario, but we've faced several problems since we bought this car. 

Even our second service was missed, and we have no idea why.Zoeb Ujjainwala#tatapunchreview#sanghibrothers#tata#tatacustomerservice Hi Raju, we're concerned to hear about the problems you've faced and we'd like to help you with this. Please share your contact number via Instagram DM (https://bit.ly/3DJnSEC), so we can have the relevant team assist you soon. similar to 80% load factor in Diesel generators, have 70% mileage for safer travel.

Traffic / idling / AC / music / sunroof / devices charging etc all consume the battery power.

It takes time to get accustomed to ev range.

Plan not to get stranded and panic for charging points. To view or add a comment,sign in Create your free account or sign in to continue your search Don‚Äôt have the app? Get it in the Microsoft Store.

By clicking Continue to join or sign in, you agree to LinkedIn‚ÄôsUser Agreement,Privacy Policy, andCookie Policy. üö® My Tata Punch Experience ‚Äì 9 Workshop Visits in 3 Months! üö®

In just 90 days, I‚Äôve visited the Tata workshop 9 times for brake, AC, and indicator issues.

Mr. Karun Grover (CRM Head, NCR) gives contradictory statements on calls and disconnects when I start recording for proof ‚Äî even saying ‚ÄúIf you record, I won‚Äôt talk.‚Äù

Tata claims my Tata Punch is ‚Äúroadworthy‚Äù and asks me to pick it up ‚Äî yet refuses to give written answers to my brake-related queries.

Is this how Tata Motors ensures customer safety? Thank you for acknowledging my concern. However, this issue has been ongoing for over 3 months with 9 service visits, and I have already provided all details multiple times. I request that your team provide me with a clear written resolution and a specific timeline instead of further delays. I will be waiting for your update till tomorrow EOD Same to same, I am having hard time with tata tigor.. since thr day it is purchased had to visit every now and then and some part is being replaced. Pathetic service with pathetic leadership at tata motors. post_text:
By clicking Continue to join or sign in, you agree to LinkedIn‚ÄôsUser Agreement,Privacy Policy, andCookie Policy. I usually don‚Äôt write such posts, but after my experience with Tata Punch and the after-sales service, I feel it‚Äôs important to share.
Right after purchasing, the AC compressor failed and had to be replaced.

A few months later, after an accident repair at Tata Sagar Motors, Sec-62, Noida the issues only multiplied ‚Äì improper windshield fitting, mismatched paintwork, and even water leakage into the cabin and cabin light.

It‚Äôs been 8 months since, and I‚Äôm still struggling with these flaws. 

Whether it‚Äôs poor service quality or possible manufacturing defects, the experience has been disappointing to say the least.

As a customer, I trustedTata Motorsfor reliability and safety, but continuous issues like these really question that trust.

I hope Tata Motors takes note of such cases seriously and ensures better quality checks and customer support.

What‚Äôs your take on this,Tata Motors? Tata MotorsThis is one of the problems. 
There are more like every IGL Pump denies to fill CNG in Tata Car because of different Nozzle. We have to wait in the lines to fill cng and what we got in return that we can‚Äôt fill cng in tata cars. Dear Mr. Bhardwaj, we‚Äôre sorry to hear about the problems you‚Äôve faced. We‚Äôd like to help you with this. Please share contact number via DM, and we‚Äôll have our team assist you as soon as possible. Haa haa always keep a bucket with you. Tata Motors its very common issues customer care people will send a general message we are sorry to hear and will try to solve the problem ASAP but later Tata they will put some M Seal and return you the same vehicle and they will give one PKT M Seal also and for next time they will show you how apply. For me for 35 lakhs I got defective Tata safari day 1 within 100 kms while coming out of the showroom engine burnt out timing chain broke while driving and came out. Initially they don't worry we will try for replacement later they told they replaced all parts with atmost care so I have to take the same defective car. When I asked for replacement they told me to proceed legally now fighting legally for replacement. Now without car Iam paying my EMI this is present Tata after the Demise of our great late RATAN Tata.  If you need any help call me 7736733440. Tata Motors, you are requested to look into this matter and provide an appropriate resolution at the earliest. The brand that Tata represents is being undermined, either due to manufacturing defects or because your service center staff are not adequately trained to address the issues faced by customers. 
We expect a prompt and satisfactory resolution at the earliest. To view or add a comment,sign in Create your free account or sign in to continue your search Don‚Äôt have the app? Get it in the Microsoft Store.

post_text:
By clicking Continue to join or sign in, you agree to LinkedIn‚ÄôsUser Agreement,Privacy Policy, andCookie Policy. Around 29,000 people lost their lives in road accidents on national highways in just the first six months of 2025.

That‚Äôs already more than 50% of last year‚Äôs total.
And this is data for only half the year.

It‚Äôs a reminder that most accidents don‚Äôt happen at extreme speeds or in rare situations. They happen during everyday drives - on familiar roads.

This Tata Punch crash video with a truck made me slow down and watch it till the end.

It felt like something that could happen on any Indian road, any day.

A truck impact at regular driving speed.
The kind of situation you never plan for.
Yet the car holds its shape far better than you‚Äôd expect.

If you drive in India, you already know how unpredictable it can be:

* sudden lane changes
* heavy vehicles appearing out of nowhere
* potholes you spot a second too late

That‚Äôs where safety stops being a line on a brochure and starts becoming a real decision - especially when you‚Äôre choosing a car for your family.

Seeing how the Punch holds up reinforces whyTata Motorshas been pushing safety as a default, not a premium.

The Punch feels confident on the road, and more importantly, reassuring when things don‚Äôt go as planned.

Safety first. Meanwhile wagonr testing with bajaj platina üòù That‚Äôs why I just loveTata Motorsmore than any other cars in India. Must watch video! Tata is best when it comes to safety ! Everyday drives carry hidden risks.

Moments like this underline why safety decisions should be boring, practical, and made long before accidents happen. Safety is a responsibility.
Eye opener This really highlights how crucial real-world safety features are. It‚Äôs reassuring to see Tata Punch performing well in situations many drivers face daily. The truck impact looked like something that could happen any day. It‚Äôs a reminder that real-world safety is the kind you feel, not just read about. Seeing the Punch take that impact really puts safety into perspective.
It‚Äôs one thing to read about ratings, and another to see how a car actually holds up. To view or add a comment,sign in Create your free account or sign in to continue your search Don‚Äôt have the app? Get it in the Microsoft Store.

By clicking Continue to join or sign in, you agree to LinkedIn‚ÄôsUser Agreement,Privacy Policy, andCookie Policy. At Oracle, I optimize algorithms for speed.
More power. Less load. Better performance.

Same principle applies to cars, I realized.

At ‚Çπ5.59 lakhs,Tata GroupPunch is priced like most hatchbacks.
But it delivers SUV stance with unmatched performance.

That's the engineering parallel.
More power. Lighter build. It also now comes with iTurbo taking performance to the next level

It's not just about acceleration.
It's about overtaking confidence on highways.
Climbing ghats without struggle.

Most micro-SUVs compromise on power for price.
Punch doesn't.

Engineering isn't about adding more.
It's about balancing right.

Like writing efficient code.
Like choosing the right tool for the job.

Same price. Different value. What's your favourite budget car? Right tool. Right price. Right performance. Engineering logic applied to buying decisions changes everything. iTurbo in this segment changes buyer calculations completely. Performance is no longer premium-only feature now. Efficient code runs faster. Efficient cars perform better. Same principles. Universal application across domains. At ‚Çπ5.59 lakhs, this spec sheet is hard to beat. Value engineering at its finest. Hatchback price, SUV presence, strong performance. That's three wins in one purchase decision right there. Most people optimize for wrong variables. Mileage over performance. Brand over specs. Emotions over logic. Punch is a great choice for 1st time buyersSanika jainLet's connect. Redefining What an Entry-Level SUV Can Be
Tata Motors has once again proven that affordable does not mean basic ‚Äî especially when safety, design, and reliability are non-negotiable.
The Tata Punch is not just a compact SUV; it‚Äôs a bold statement for customers who want strong build quality, modern design, and uncompromised safety in one package.
üí∞ Price Range (India | Ex-Showroom):
üëâ Starts at ~‚Çπ6 lakh
üëâ Goes up to ~‚Çπ10 lakh, depending on variant
üîç Why Tata Punch stands out in its segment:
‚úî 5-Star Global NCAP Safety Rating ‚Äì a benchmark for the category
‚úî SUV-inspired bold design with high ground clearance
‚úî Engineered for Indian roads and real-world driving conditions
‚úî Balanced performance with impressive fuel efficiency
‚úî Backed by the trust and legacy of Tata Motors
In today‚Äôs market, buyers are no longer choosing cars based only on mileage.
They are investing in safety, durability, and long-term value ‚Äî and Tata Punch delivers exactly that.
üìå Business insight from Tata Punch:
A product doesn‚Äôt have to be big to create a big impact.
Strong fundamentals and clear value positioning always win the market.
üëè Kudos to Tata Motors for raising the bar in the entry-level SUV segment.
üí¨ What‚Äôs your take on the Tata Punch?
Is it the best choice in its category?
